questions.question_text:
A company recently implemented a variety of security services to detect various types of traffic that pose a threat to the company. The following services were enabled within the network:
* Scan of specific subsets for vulnerabilities
* Categorizing and logging of website traffic
* Enabling specific ACLs based on application traffic
* Sending suspicious files to a third-party site for validation
A report was sent to the security team that identified multiple incidents of users sharing large amounts of data from an on-premise server to a public site. A small percentage of that data also contained malware and spyware
Which of the following services MOST likely identified the behavior and sent the report?

comments.content: I am *not* sure that UBA is supposed to detect malware.

I agree with B, user behavior analytics. It mentions on premise servers, to me that rules out CSB. Also it says a report was sent mentioning the large amount of data. It does not say the malware was identified in the report.

discussion.content:
Any chance this could be: F. Cloud security broker ? 
A CASB can do an lot. Also, I am sure that UBA is supposed to detect malware. 
"What is user behavior analytics (UBA)?"
https://www.splunk.com/en_us/data-insider/user-behavior-analytics-ueba.html

questions.question_text:
An external red team member conducts a penetration test, attempting to gain physical access to a large organization's server room in a branch office. During reconnaissance, the red team member sees a clearly marked door to the server room, located next to the lobby, with a tumbler lock.
Which of the following is BEST for the red team member to bring on site to open the locked door as quickly as possible without causing significant damage?

discussion.content:
Going with B.
I think the answer has to be bump key. You can open a standard tumbler lock in under 5 seconds pretty easily with a bump key, I've never seen a pick set (rake picking isn't something you bring, it's a technique using rake picks--also makes me suspicious). I've also never seen a bump key cause SIGNIFICANT damage, and honestly using a good bump blank is likely to not even leave a scratch.

I don’t like this one... “quickly as possible” and the fact that it is in the lobby where you will be seen makes me want to choose bump key. But there is a chance the bump key can damage the lock.... I just don’t see you being able to use rake picks quickly or in the lobby.

choices.D: Accept the risk and upgrade the ICS when possible
choices.C: Mitigate the risk by restricting access to the ICS
choices.A: Avoid the risk by removing the ICS from production
choices.B: Transfer the risk associated with the ICS vulnerabilities

comments.content: Getting an insurance for the equipment is different from transferring the risk associated with the vulnerabilities of the equipment. So the given answer "Transfer the risk..." is correct

discussion.content:
The risk cannot be transferred because Insurance companies will not insure the ICS equipment.
C. Mitigate the risk by restricting access to the ICS - is the most feasible option in this scenario.
Going with C on this one

Maybe: D. Accept the risk and upgrade the ICS when possible?
I see no reason to assume there is another ICS provider, or a managed service, for the mandatory monitoring. The company cannot do without the monitoring, the company cannot insure against risks. I would assume that access to the ICS is already restricted, and restricting access does not remove the vulnerabilities. I don't see where the company has any choice but to live with the vulnerabilities until the ICS can be replaced (I assume that is what they mean by "upgraded").

comments.content: I think that using another managed service would be mitigating the risk.

Restricting access to the ICS would mitigate the risk because less people have access to it. That said, I cannot imagine any company offering unrestricted access to it's ICS. I would assume access is already restricted. 
The question offers no indication that another ICS, or managed service, is available.
Using another managed service for the mandatory monitoring does not necessarily transfer the risk. That only transfers the duties.

discussion.content: Restricting access to the ICS does not remediate the vulnerabilities, and being unable to patch or update makes it sound like the ICS is End-of-Life. Transfer the risk by using another managed service for the mandatory monitoring. Risk transference isn't just insurance, it most often refers to contracting out risk in the form of services rendered so that a 3rd party accepts the risk, not just insurance companies.

questions.question_text:
A company relies on an ICS to perform equipment monitoring functions that are federally mandated for operation of the facility. Fines for non-compliance could be costly. The ICS has known vulnerabilities and can no longer be patched or updated. Cyber-liability insurance cannot be obtained because insurance companies will not insure this equipment.
Which of the following would be the BEST option to manage this risk to the company's production environment?

During a sprint, developers are responsible for ensuring the expected outcome of a change is thoroughly evaluated for any security impacts. Any impacts must be reported to the team lead. Before changes are made to the source code, which of the following MUST be performed to provide the required information to the team lead?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
testing needs to develop with each sprint and testers must make sure that new changes do not affect existing functionality of the application. This is known as regression testing.

Maybe: A. Risk assessment ? 
As TheThreatGuy noted: the question states "before changes are made to the source code." 
Risk assessment: determines possible mishaps, their likelihood and consequences, and the tolerances for such events.

Maybe: E. Business impact assessment ?
From the question: ". . . for any security impacts. Any impacts must be . . ." The repeated use of the word "impact" makes me wonder if they may want an "impact analysis."
The question states, "before changes are made to the code". A storyboard is the answer.

comments.content: You're overthinking it. "During a sprint" developers need to do regression testing before they commit the code from dev to prod. B is the correct answer.

discussion.content: “Before changes are made to the source code”. This has to be risk assessment. Regression testing will be after the change.

comments.content:
Data deduplication removes data redundancies, making the data "more precise" if you will
Answers is BF

discussion.content:
I'm saying BD: 
TLDR: Data Deduplication will reduce the overall amount of data

What is data deduplication and why is it important?
Data deduplication works by finding portions of files that are identical and storing just a single copy of the duplicated data on the disk.
Data deduplication is important because it significantly reduces your storage space needs, saving you money and reducing how much bandwidth is wasted on transferring data to/from remote storage locations
Going with the given answer BF

Maybe: C. Data isolation ?
Again: the question is about compliance with regulatory requirements. Data precision has nothing to do with such requirements. Data isolation may be, at least remotely, associated with such requirements. 
Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/data-isolation

The question is about compliance with regulatory requirements.
Data sovereignty refers to the concept that the data an organization collects, stores, and processes is subject to the nation's laws and general best practices where it is physically located.
The rest of the options do not deal with compliance with regulatory requirements.

I'm not sure what F. Data precision has to do with the sanitization other than when they're doing the dedupe its going to some how be more "precise". The good news is that it's the only 2nd answer that looks anywhere close to being possible. :-)

questions.question_text: An organization is currently working with a client to migrate data between a legacy ERP system and a cloud-based ERP tool using a global PaaS provider. As part of the engagement, the organization is performing data deduplication and sanitization of client data to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for the need to sanitize the client data? (Choose two.)
